rules: Rule1: The cobra does not pay money to the songbird, in the case where the fish disarms the cobra. Rule2: The cobra will pay some $$$ to the songbird if it (the cobra) has a name whose first letter is the same as the first letter of the duck's name.
example: A few players are playing a boardgame. The current state of the game is as follows. The duck is named Tango. The fish disarms the cobra. And the rules of the game are as follows. Rule1: The cobra does not pay money to the songbird, in the case where the fish disarms the cobra. Rule2: The cobra will pay some $$$ to the songbird if it (the cobra) has a name whose first letter is the same as the first letter of the duck's name. Rule2 is preferred over Rule1. Based on the game state and the rules and preferences, does the cobra pay money to the songbird?
proof: We know the fish disarms the cobra, and according to Rule1 "if the fish disarms the cobra, then the cobra does not pay money to the songbird", and for the conflicting and higher priority rule Rule2 we cannot prove the antecedent "the cobra has a name whose first letter is the same as the first letter of the duck's name", so we can conclude "the cobra does not pay money to the songbird". So the statement "the cobra pays money to the songbird" is disproved and the answer is "no".

	Rule2: (cobra, has a name whose first letter is the same as the first letter of the, duck's name) => (cobra, pay, songbird)

	Rule2 > Rule1
